security_audit.summary: Official skill from Anthropic with no suspicious code or network actions. Contains only documentation and examples for creating Hookify rules.

content.user_title: Create Hookify rules with correct syntax
content.value_statement: You need reliable Hookify rules but the format can be confusing. This skill gives clear structure, events, and pattern guidance.
actual_capabilities: Explains required frontmatter fields and valid event types
Shows basic and advanced rule formats with conditions
Lists condition fields and supported operators
Provides regex tips, examples, and common pitfalls
Describes file naming and organization rules
limitations: Does not validate rules against a live Hookify engine
Does not generate or edit files automatically
Does not test regex patterns for you

use_cases.title: Guard risky commands
use_cases.description: Create bash rules that warn or block unsafe shell commands.

use_cases.title: Stop debug code
use_cases.description: Add file rules that detect console.log or debugger in code changes.

use_cases.title: Enforce process steps
use_cases.description: Use stop rules to remind teams to run tests before ending work.

prompt_templates.title: Start a bash rule
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Hookify bash rule that blocks rm -rf usage and explains safer alternatives.

prompt_templates.title: File rule for secrets
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a file rule that warns when editing .env files and mentions adding them to .gitignore.

prompt_templates.title: Multi condition rule
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a rule using conditions to warn about console.log in .ts or .tsx files.

prompt_templates.title: Stop checklist
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a stop rule that reminds users to run tests and update documentation before finishing.

output_examples.input: Make a rule to warn on sudo usage in bash commands
output: Rule name uses kebab case and a clear verb
Event is bash with a regex for sudo
Message warns about privilege escalation and suggests safer steps

best_practices: Use specific regex patterns to avoid false positives
Name rules with clear verbs and scope
Keep messages short and action oriented
anti_patterns: Using overly broad patterns like log

faq.question: Is this compatible with my Hookify setup?
faq.answer: It targets standard Hookify rule files and events described in the skill.

faq.question: Are there limits on pattern complexity?
faq.answer: Rules support Python style regex, but very complex patterns may be hard to maintain.

faq.question: Can it integrate with my existing rules?
faq.answer: Yes, it follows the same file format and naming conventions.

faq.question: Does it send data outside my machine?
faq.answer: No, it only provides guidance and examples.

faq.question: What if a rule does not trigger?
faq.answer: Check the event type, pattern accuracy, and enabled flag.

faq.question: How does it compare to general regex guides?
faq.answer: It is focused on Hookify fields, events, and rule structure.
